original_transcript: Today is February 1st, 2024 and we are in the endoscopy suite. This is Dr. ABC performing an ERCP with stent removal, cannulation of the papilla and stent placement on a 19-year-old male. Indications for the procedure is follow up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis, initial concern for malignancy, but prior biopsies and imaging showed no evidence of progression, suggesting a benign etiology. The patient has undergone serial ERCPs since 2017 with the last ERCP performed in August 2020, during which a 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent was placed. He now returns for re-examination and stent exchange. I'm beginning the procedure. The patient is in a left semi-prone position and intravenous sedation was administered. I'm advancing the Olympus TJF Q180V duodenoscope was advanced through the mouth, esophagus and stomach, reaching the second part of the duodenum without difficulty. The ERCP finding shows a scout film confirmed the presence of a biliary stent in situ. The duodenoscope was advanced without a detailed upper J-examination. A single plastic stent was visualized at the major papilla and successfully removed using a snare. The prior biliary sphincterotomy was found to be patent. The bile duct was deeply cannulated using a sphincterotome, preloaded with a 0.035-inch guide wire, which was advanced into the intrahepatic ducts with ease. A cholangiogram revealed a mild, short, highlarge structure measuring approximately 5 mm, extending from the hilum bile duct successfully. The scope is now completely withdrawn. There was minimal blood loss. There were no immediate complications. The procedure was successfully completed. End of procedure.

raw.chief_complaints: follow up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis
raw.symptoms_description: Initial concern for malignancy, but prior biopsies and imaging showed no evidence of progression, suggesting a benign etiology.
raw.negative_history: no evidence of progression of malignancy
raw.past_medical_history: history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis
raw.stricture_description: mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm, extending from the hilum
raw.prior_stent_status: single plastic stent visualized at the major papilla and successfully removed
raw.impressions: ['Successful removal of prior 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent', 'Patent prior biliary sphincterotomy', 'Successful deep cannulation of bile duct with sphincterotome and guidewire', 'Cholangiogram revealed mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm', 'Successful placement of new 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent']

rendered_sections.indications: 19-year-old male patient is here for an ERCP procedure for follow up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis.
rendered_sections.history:
The patient reports  history of follow up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis.
Initial concern for malignancy, but prior biopsies and imaging showed no evidence of progression, suggesting a benign etiology.
 No history of no evidence of progression of malignancy is reported unless otherwise specified.History of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis.
rendered_sections.description_of_procedure: After the risks, benefits and alternatives of the procedure were thoroughly explained, informed consent was verified, confirmed and timeout was successfully executed by the treatment team. With the patient in the left semi-prone position, medications were administered intravenously. The duodenoscope Olympus TJF Q180V was passed from the mouth into the esophagus and further advanced from the esophagus into the stomach. From the stomach, the scope was directed to the second portion of the duodenum.
rendered_sections.findings:
A scout film of the abdomen was performed. It appeared normal. biliary stent in situ.

The duodenoscope Olympus TJF Q180V was advanced to the second portion of the duodenum without difficulty and without detailed examination of the upper GI tract.
 Not described were seen.
The major papilla was identified. It appeared normal in position and morphology, with an intact orifice and no surrounding erythema or edema.After removal of the previously placed stent, evidence of prior sphincterotomy was present. Orifice was patent.A previously placed plastic or metal stent was seen emerging from the major papilla.
The minor papilla could not be located.

The ampulla was identified and found to be normal.

Bile duct cannulation was attempted using a sphincterotome preloaded with a guidewire (0.035-inch guide wire).
Bile duct cannulation was successful. Biliary cannulation was achieved without pancreatic duct entry.

Contrast was injected under fluoroscopic guidance and cholangiogram was performed.
 Intrahepatic ducts were normal in caliber, and contrast drained freely into the duodenum. Mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm, extending from the hilum. Single plastic stent visualized at the major papilla and successfully removed.
Pancreatogram was not performed.

Sphincterotomy was performed.

A 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent was placed. The scope was then completely withdrawn from the patient and the procedure completed.

Estimated blood loss: None.

Specimens removed: None.

Complications: There were no immediate complications.

Rectal indomethacin: No.
Successful completion of intended procedure: Yes.
Failed ERCP from another facility or provider: No.

4. Cholangiogram revealed mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm
5. Successful placement of new 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent

1. Finish IV fluids now.
2. Pain control as needed.
3. Follow up with referring provider.

rendered_note:
## Indications
19-year-old male patient is here for an ERCP procedure for follow up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis.

## Medications
Refer to record of source.

## Monitoring
Johns Hopkins Standard.

## History
The patient reports  history of follow up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis.
Initial concern for malignancy, but prior biopsies and imaging showed no evidence of progression, suggesting a benign etiology.
 No history of no evidence of progression of malignancy is reported unless otherwise specified.History of hilar biliary stricture and chronic thalassification pancreatitis.

## Description Of Procedure
After the risks, benefits and alternatives of the procedure were thoroughly explained, informed consent was verified, confirmed and timeout was successfully executed by the treatment team. With the patient in the left semi-prone position, medications were administered intravenously. The duodenoscope Olympus TJF Q180V was passed from the mouth into the esophagus and further advanced from the esophagus into the stomach. From the stomach, the scope was directed to the second portion of the duodenum.

## Findings
A scout film of the abdomen was performed. It appeared normal. biliary stent in situ.

The duodenoscope Olympus TJF Q180V was advanced to the second portion of the duodenum without difficulty and without detailed examination of the upper GI tract.
 Not described were seen.
The major papilla was identified. It appeared normal in position and morphology, with an intact orifice and no surrounding erythema or edema.After removal of the previously placed stent, evidence of prior sphincterotomy was present. Orifice was patent.A previously placed plastic or metal stent was seen emerging from the major papilla.
The minor papilla could not be located.

The ampulla was identified and found to be normal.

Bile duct cannulation was attempted using a sphincterotome preloaded with a guidewire (0.035-inch guide wire).
Bile duct cannulation was successful. Biliary cannulation was achieved without pancreatic duct entry.

Contrast was injected under fluoroscopic guidance and cholangiogram was performed.
 Intrahepatic ducts were normal in caliber, and contrast drained freely into the duodenum. Mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm, extending from the hilum. Single plastic stent visualized at the major papilla and successfully removed.
Pancreatogram was not performed.

Sphincterotomy was performed.

A 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent was placed. The scope was then completely withdrawn from the patient and the procedure completed.

Estimated blood loss: None.

Specimens removed: None.

Complications: There were no immediate complications.

## Ercp Quality Metrics
Difficulty of ERCP:  pancreatic duct cannulation not attempted.
Cannulation success: Yes.
Post-ERCP pancreatitis prophylaxis:No.
Rectal indomethacin: No.
Successful completion of intended procedure: Yes.
Failed ERCP from another facility or provider: No.

## Impressions
1. Successful removal of prior 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent
2. Patent prior biliary sphincterotomy
3. Successful deep cannulation of bile duct with sphincterotome and guidewire
4. Cholangiogram revealed mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm
5. Successful placement of new 10 French into 15 cm plastic stent

## Recommendations
1. Finish IV fluids now.
2. Pain control as needed.
3. Follow up with referring provider.
